course.subject: LANG
course.name: Chinese for Non-Chinese Language Background Students VII
course.description: This course builds on the groundwork laid in LANG 1120, LANG 1121 and LANG 1122 and LANG 1123, LANG 1124 and LANG 1125, and takes students to a high level of understanding of spoken Chinese and a stronger communicative competence in using Chinese in social and professional situations. Restricted to students with non-Chinese language backgrounds only. Students without the prerequisite but with approximate 300 hours of prior Chinese learning experience or attained level 5 in the HSK Chinese Proficiency Test may seek instructorâ€™s approval for enrollment in the course.
course.exclusions: HKDSE/HKALE/HKCEE/JEE Chinese, LANG 1110 (prior to 2013-14), LANG 1111 (prior to 2013-14), LANG 1112 (prior to 2016-17), LANG 1113, LANG 1114, LANG 1115, LANG 1116

reviews.author: Spencer Dee
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
1. China's Development
2. Prosperous Shanghai
3. Amazing Beijing
4. China's territory
5. Life of Chinese citizens
6. Aegean Sea
7. Bali
8. Machu Picchu
reviews.comment_teaching: laoshi is really kind and really enjoys teaching the class. she always extends deadlines and is very approachable when you need help.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading
if you skip 5 classes then you fail the course
the midterm quiz was not so hard; lifted directly from the powerpoints so if you study those and the vocabulary you should be fine
reviews.comment_workload: Mostly just essays to submit and a few oral presentations to prepare for

reviews.author: jhs
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
1. China's Development
2. Prosperous Shanghai
3. Amazing Beijing
4. China's territory
5. Life of Chinese citizens
6. Aegean Sea
7. Bali
8. Machu Picchu

The contents are pretty helpful if you genuinely study hard.

sometimes, I feel like class structure is not fully representing the book material.
reviews.comment_teaching:
generous instructor. kind-hearted and quite flexible with deadlines.
very passionate
open to any question and feed backs.
reviews.comment_grading: good, if you work on ppt, attend the class, write proper level of the essay ( ask your Chinese friend to proofread) concentrate during the lecture and make sure you know all the vocabularies.

reviews.author: CourseReviewer
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
1. China's Development
2. Prosperous Shanghai
3. Amazing Beijing
4. China's territory
5. Life of Chinese citizens
6. Aegean Sea
7. Bali
8. Machu Picchu

The content is actually interesting. You learn a lot of Chinese idioms, which may or may not be used in daily life. Many new vocabulary for me.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Teaching is average. The instructor sometimes creates group discussions. In addition, she tries to have each group do a short 3-4 minute presentation about each lesson. In my opinion, this just adds to the workload.

Probably the fact that it's a 9 am class makes it even worse to me.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is absolute, not relative.

As far as I know, the instructor told me that 90% and above is certainly in the A range, around 85% will be in the B+/A- range.

The instructor is relatively strict about the structure of sentences in the "Making Sentences" part of the written test. Even if you know the meaning of the words, it is quite difficult to create a sentence with exact, good grammar.

Don't miss more than 5 classes, it's an automatic fail. Other than that, attendance does not affect your grading (But it does affect your instructor's perception of you!)
reviews.comment_workload:
Although there is not much homework, the exams are very, very time-consuming.

The mid-term exam consists of a 25% written test, a 10% essay, and a 20% oral presentation.

The essay has to be approximately 600 words, based on the topic "China in my Eyes".

The individual oral presentation is a maximum of 3 minutes, with the topic of your favorite Chinese city.

The written test was on the first 5 chapters, this one is relatively easier than the others.


Finals are also quite time-consuming; it consists of a 20% group oral presentation and a 25% essay.

The group oral presentation was just newly introduced this term. Your group has to make a presentation about various vacation spots of a city/country (except China) for different target audiences (such as honeymoon couple, elderly people, university students, wildlife adventurers, etc). Each group has to speak for about 10 to 15 minutes, and powerpoints are allowed.

The essay is also about attracting your target audience to a certain country/city, promoting the famous scenic spots. You also have to make a travel schedule. This essay should be around 800 words.
